importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Retail coffee prices jumped nearly 21% in August 2025 compared to the same period the previous year, indicating a direct economic impact of tariffs on consumer spending.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from July to September 2025 marks when tariffs were implemented and the bipartisan 'No Coffee Tax Act' was introduced, showing legislative response to economic pressures.

keyTakeAways: The Trump administration's tariffs on coffee imports—50% on Brazil, 20% on Vietnam, and 10% on Colombia—are driving up the cost of coffee beans for U.S. roasters.
The U.S. imports over 99% of its coffee, with Brazil supplying 30.7% of imports, followed by Colombia (18.3%) and Vietnam (6.6%).
Retail coffee prices increased by nearly 21% in August 2025 compared to the same month in 2024; the average price of a restaurant coffee rose to $3.52, with cold brews at $5.35.
Coffee roasters like Swing’s Coffee Roasters, Vigilante Coffee Company, and Celtic Cup Coffee Roasting report increased costs, with beans rising from $4 to $6 per pound and up to $1 per 12-ounce bag.
Tariff-related costs have led some roasters to diversify sourcing from countries like Indonesia, Ethiopia, and Colombia to mitigate price volatility.
Consumers may shift brands or seek deals, but are unlikely to abandon coffee entirely due to its status as an affordable luxury.
Small businesses face uncertainty and financial pressure due to unpredictable pricing and tariff volatility.
A bipartisan legislative effort—the 'No Coffee Tax Act' introduced by Rep. Don Bacon (Nebraska) and Rep. Ro Khanna (California)—aims to exempt coffee products from tariffs to stabilize prices.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Trump administration's imposition of steep tariffs—50% on Brazil, 20% on Vietnam, and 10% on Colombia—is significantly increasing the cost of imported coffee beans, leading to a 21% rise in retail coffee prices in August 2025. As the U.S. imports over 99% of its coffee, with Brazil being the largest supplier, these tariffs directly impact roasters like Swing’s Coffee Roasters, Vigilante Coffee Company, and Celtic Cup Coffee Roasting, who report higher bean prices and financial strain. Consumers in major cities like Washington, D.C., are seeing prices rise, though they are unlikely to abandon coffee due to its status as an affordable luxury. In response, a bipartisan group of lawmakers, including Rep. Don Bacon and Rep. Ro Khanna, introduced the 'No Coffee Tax Act' to exempt coffee from tariffs, aiming to stabilize prices and protect consumers and small businesses facing unpredictable costs due to global supply chain disruptions and tariff volatility.
title: Trump’s Tariffs Are Brewing Trouble for Coffee Roasters
